author: shahzad chaudhry
title: Deep state and American politics
text: The two principal political protagonists were well defined, except when the 82-year-old President Biden decided against running for reelection against the 78-year-old Donald Trump who has returned to the fray after a gap of four years. Trump is Trump with a colourful record both as the President and as a person. Yet the Republicans thought of him as the more energetic and more populist candidate of the two who could win them back the White House. Biden was considered an ageing, tiring, senile and a forgetful candidate who had lost both his verve and his spright. The Presidents are usually the presumptive nominees if they have another term to contest. When Biden decided to withdraw it was unprecedented and hence a surprise, yet not a surprise because most on the Democrat side of the contest wished him to leave the field to someone who could have even or better chances to retain the White House. He was thus eulogised in laudable terms even as he was being kicked out of the running in what was being considered an almost certain defeat for the Democrats. Biden had turned into a sicker copy of himself and increasingly faltered on the global stage. Yet when he threw in the towel it was a day of bewilderment in political terms. Only on two earlier occasions in history had a sitting president decided not to seek another term. Biden had done well domestically, on the economic front and the USA has felt like a country on rails after the twin shocks of Covid and threatening recession. But with increasing age he had turned into a grandfather who could relate tricks from an old man's repertoire but was not the person that relatives wanted on display to visiting neighbours. It took quite an effort to convince him to withdraw. His wife and his close family though believed that in his bid for reelection stood the chance for their collective good. Equally amusingly, Dr Jill Biden, President's wife, was called for elderly abuse. (Pun was surely intended). Yet, it was the possibility of Trump's success in the election that became the trigger of concern on both sides of the aisle where some Republicans too openly beseeched the Democrats to review their nomination. Given the late state in the campaign it carried its own predicament, but a victorious Trump was a bigger risk. And this is why. Trump has declared that on Day-1 in his next tenure he will withdraw support to Ukraine which he feels has drained off billions of precious American dollars. If it implicitly delivers a victory to Putin with whom he claims an affable understanding and relationship so be it. America and 'making it great again' comes first to him. Without American support Ukraine and Zelenskyy has no legs to stand on against the superpower might of Russia. Ukraine till date has been collectively propped against Russia to keep Russia at bay from flexing its muscles in a newfound zeal to expand its perimeter of security against an encroaching NATO. From a deep state perspective, a Trump win would dislodge US' strategy. Trump's two other policy stands differ significantly from how policy gurus, 'deep state' thinkers and strategists prescribe: these relate to China and US policy on Israel. On Israel, Trump may not differ much except that he would ask Netanyahu to expedite the end game and use whatever will help him achieve that end. Trump's approach will put paid to the declared two-state policy that USA has publicly espoused and take an already obnoxious and dastardly war to even higher levels of intensity failing the morality test. With that will also go down the ultimate US aim to enable Israel the credibility needed to act as the minder of its interests in the ME failing to find US' proxy in the ME the desired eminence and acceptability. The design is grand enough to have withstood the tenures of both Trump and Biden. Trump would derail the entire effort. On China, Trump is far more aggressive than a revamped Biden who in his turn did not wish to appear a wimp after Trump in his first tenure had slapped tariffs and restrictions on China in a bid to slow and weaken its economy. Trump's affability towards Putin while attacking China on multifarious economic fronts was a typical recourse to super-power trinity games. Biden kept those pressures going only slowly relenting on some when faced with the reality of an imminent recession following Covid and global economic slowdown. While Biden kept a more offensive face on Russia, he tried working with China through his interlocutors to keep the economy improving globally and for the US. Trump's vow to raise tariffs on Chinese goods to the tune of 70 per cent to many in the US is a sure recipe to invite deepening recession. Inflation will be the other consequence slowing down American recovery and growth. Clearly American deep state is not in on this ride. Enter the Deep State. It needed Biden to abdicate his option for the second term and let Kamala Harris in as an establishment protÃ©gÃ©. She will continue the policies of Biden aligned with American deep state objectives. Given this reading it may seem Harris has more than a fair chance to carry the November election while most odds are stacked against Trump despite his populist appeal - Republicans have their own set of anti-Trumpers who may simply abstain on the voting day or vote Harris is a few cases. All to keep Trump out. Yet it is the people who will decide the outcome. Deep state can only set the game up. What is deep state then? In bringing Biden to submit there was an unannounced but vehement pressure of the Democrat establishment. It constitutes of former Presidents, Democrat stalwarts and think-tanks who design Democrat policy and give it the words for enunciation. Just as there is a Republican establishment which feels to win back the White House, the pinnacle of American power, Trump is their best bet. Once in hand they can then force Trump to toe their line, they hope. Deep state sits over both establishments and has contributors and constituents from both sides in former Presidents, retired and serving CIA heads and deep state policy thinkers who keep above power politics to focus entirely on what is good for America. That it reflects what is genuinely good for the US, its people and retains American primacy in the world rarely varying from how a matter is largely perceived by the thinking quarters. The match-up in November is thus between Deep State/ Establishment appointee and Donald Trump's populism. The people will decide who wins. COMMENTS Comments are moderated and generally will be posted if they are on-topic and not abusive. For more information, please see our [Comments FAQ](/comments-policy)

author: KOMO News Staff
title: chevron-right
text: SEATTLE â€” REI CEO Eric Artz announced Thursday the company is laying off 357 employees as it braces for what's expected to be a "challenging" year ahead. [According to the message shared with employees](https://www.rei.com/newsroom/article/reductions-to-our-workforce), the layoffs will impact 200 people at headquarters, six from sales and customer support, 30 from experiences, meaning classes and trips, and 121 in distribution centers. No non-headquarters store-specific roles will be impacted. Artz said every employee whose job is eliminated will be getting separation benefits including severance, COBRA, and outplacement support and services. The coming days are going to be tough as we let go of a lot of good people," Artz said. "Weâ€™re going to do everything we can to support them, but that will not make this moment any easier. The company added it does not plan to backfill recent leadership departures and instead will "take the opportunity to right-size" its senior leadership team to the needs of the business. Altogether, Artz said the company is reducing the size of its senior leadership team by 22% in 2024. Artz said the layoffs come as outdoor specialty retail has experienced major declines over the last four quarters and is continuing to worsen. "While we were able to outperform this trend for much of the last year, it caught up to us in Q4 and we now expect conditions to remain very challenging throughout 2024," said Artz. The company is planning for 2024's revenue to be down from 2023, which means it is adjusting "plans and cost structure accordingly." In February 2023, The company, [REI laid off more than 160 people](https://komonews.com/news/local/rei-announces-layoffs-at-seattle-headquarters-kent-washington-king-county-amazon-microsoft) as it anticipated worsening economic conditions for the business last year. Artz said Thursday in his letter, "We must also continue our work to return REI to profitability to set the co-op up for long-term health and success."

author: EFE
title: Investigan la quema y el robo de papeletas electorales en Arizona y Florida
text:
Las autoridades de Estados Unidos investigan el incendio de un buzÃ³n del Servicio Postal (USPS, en inglÃ©s) con papeletas de voto anticipado y 3 ataques a la sede de campaÃ±a de la vicepresidenta Kamala Harris, en hechos ocurridos en Arizona, como tambiÃ©n el robo de boletas electorales en Florida.
Dos sospechosos han sido detenidos por los ataques electorales llevados a cabo en diferentes ciudades de la zona metropolitana de Phoenix, en el condado Maricopa de Arizona.
Al ser el mÃ¡s poblado, el condado de Maricopa es clave para definir quiÃ©n gana Arizona, un estado donde la vicepresidenta Harris y el expresidente Donald Trump estÃ¡n prÃ¡cticamente empatados.
El capitÃ¡n de bomberos de Phoenix, Rob McDade, dijo que una persona desconocida iniciÃ³ un incendio dentro de un buzÃ³n en la madrugada de hoy daÃ±ando al menos 20 papeletas electorales.
La alcaldesa de Phoenix, Kate Gallego, se mostrÃ³ preocupada por el incidente y dijo que estÃ¡ trabajando con el secretario de Estado de Arizona, Adrian Fontes, y las autoridades electorales locales para que los votantes afectados puedan emitir su voto nuevamente.
Un sospechoso fue detenido esta maÃ±ana con relaciÃ³n al incendio.
Otro incidente ocurriÃ³ en Phoenix, en donde Jeffrey Michael Kelly, de 60 aÃ±os, fue acusado este miÃ©rcoles de 3 tiroteos separados en 20 dÃ­as que daÃ±aron una oficina de campaÃ±a del ComitÃ© Nacional DemÃ³crata en un suburbio de la capital de Arizona.
Las autoridades dijeron que decenas de armas, miles de municiones y un lanzagranadas fueron recuperados de la casa de Kelly, que tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ acusado de dejar bolsas de polvo blanco en varios lugares de la ciudad de Temple.
La FiscalÃ­a de Maricopa dijo que cree que el sospechoso se estaba preparando para cometer un ataque masivo con las armas que tenÃ­a.
Entretanto, en el centro de Florida, en el condado de Orange, las autoridades investigan el robo de varias boletas de un buzÃ³n del USPS supuestamente por una persona que tenÃ­a una llave maestra.
Se encontraron alrededor de una docena de boletas descartadas cerca de un desagÃ¼e pluvial.

author: Decatur Daily Democrat
title: Realtimecampaign.com Discusses the Importance of Enhancing Operations with Fleet Management Software | News | decaturdailydemocrat.com
text: Fleet management software plays a pivotal role in the contemporary digital landscape, especially within the realm of computer security software. This technology, evolving rapidly, offers comprehensive solutions to manage, track, and maintain vehicle fleets in various industries. It integrates sophisticated software engineering with robust security measures to ensure the safety and efficiency of fleet operations. The Core of Fleet Management: Security and Efficiency The integration of fleet management software into daily operations is not just about tracking vehicles; it's about ensuring the integrity and security of data related to those vehicles. In a world where cyber threats are increasingly sophisticated, the importance of secure fleet management cannot be understated. This software typically includes features like real-time vehicle tracking, maintenance scheduling, fuel management, and driver performance monitoring. However, its core value lies in its ability to safeguard sensitive data against unauthorized access and cyber threats. Operational Efficiency and Data Management One of the key aspects of this technology is its contribution to operational efficiency, according to realtimecampaign.com. Companies using these technologies have noted significant improvements in their operations. This improvement is not just in terms of vehicle tracking but also in data management and security. By using these tools, businesses can monitor their fleet in real-time, ensuring that vehicles are being used efficiently and safely. The Emergence of Innovators in Fleet Management Another significant development in the realm of fleet management is the emergence of MetTel . This company has been at the forefront of integrating advanced technology into fleet management solutions. Their products are known for their robust security features, ensuring that the fleet data is protected against cyber threats. This is crucial in an era where data breaches can have severe financial and reputational consequences for companies. The Future of Fleet Management: 2023 and Beyond The year 2023 has seen the evolution of this software with the introduction of some of the Best Fleet Management Software of 2023 options. This new generation of software comes equipped with enhanced features like advanced analytics, improved user interfaces, and more robust security protocols. These advancements are not just about tracking and maintaining vehicles; they're about providing a comprehensive, secure, and efficient tool for managing all aspects of a fleet. Adapting to Cyber Threats in Fleet Management In the context of computer security, the significance of his response to the evolving cyber threat landscape is crucial. It highlights the need for continuous improvement and adaptation in security measures within fleet management software. As cyber threats become more sophisticated, the software must evolve to provide robust protection against potential breaches and data theft. Fleet management software stands as a testament to the power of technology in enhancing business operations while ensuring data security. Its role in the modern digital landscape is multifaceted, providing tools for efficient vehicle management, data protection, and operational optimization. As technology continues to advance, we can expect this software to become even more integral to the smooth running of fleet operations, underpinned by stringent security measures to safeguard against ever-evolving cyber threats. Media Contact Company Name: Realtimecampaign.com Contact Person: Media Relations Email: Send Email Phone: 407-875-1833 Country: United States Website: Realtimecampaign.com

author: Andrew Donlan
title: Road To $10M: How Maxim Healthcare Services Completely Revamped Its Caregiver Benefits Package
text:
Over the years, home-based care companies have thrown their weight behind
enhanced benefits packages to attract more caregivers. Maxim Healthcare Services is one example of a company taking this effort to the next level.
Last month, Maxim announced that it expanded its caregiver benefits program. The revamped benefits program is estimated to offer more than $10 million in added benefits.
The road to $10 million in added benefits began with Maximâ€™s employee survey. Every year, the company conducts a survey â€” known as the â€œvoices of experience.â€
â€œOver the course of time, our caregivers have been telling us they want more,â€ Maxim Healthcare Services CEO Jarrod DePriest News. â€œThey wanted more PTO. Generally, benefits seemed to be a common theme throughout our survey process.â€
The Maryland-based Maxim Healthcare Services provides home health care, companion care and behavioral care services.
The response from the surveys led to Maxim putting together town halls with cohorts of caregivers across the country, which took place last fall.
â€œWe had 50 or 60 caregivers from four different parts of the country, and what we found talking to the caregivers directly, was that it wasnâ€™t a one-size-fits-all approach,â€ DePriest said. â€œWhatâ€™s important to caregiver A might be different from whatâ€™s important to caregiver B.â€
After these town halls, Maximâ€™s goal was to create a compelling caregiver benefits program that caught the attention of both job seekers and longtime employees.
Maxim has changed its business model over the years. In the original business model, caregiver benefits were not always top of mind.
â€œWhen I started with Maxim 26 years ago, we started as a staffing company,â€ DePriest said. â€œIn 1993, we began to provide private-duty nursing. That was really our entrance into the home care setting. Because our origins were really staffing centric, we didnâ€™t really have a robust benefit offering.â€
In 2022, Maxim announced that it split its two business units into independently operated companies â€” Maxim Healthcare Services and Maxim Healthcare Staffing.
In order to catch up with the companyâ€™s evolution as a business, Maxim has enhanced its caregiver benefits package in a few ways. The company has increased its paid time off, almost doubling it.
Additionally, Maxim gave caregivers who work more than 2,000 hours a year the opportunity to choose between expanded PTO or cash bonuses, known as the companyâ€™s MaxCares program.
Plus, the company implemented the ability for caregivers to set up a health savings account (HSA).
The company also offers an array of family care benefits, such as parental leave and more.
With all of these enhancements in place, Maxim is looking to measure what the impact will be on the company.
â€œWeâ€™re definitely measuring both 90-day and 12-month retention rates for our caregivers,â€ DePriest said. â€œWeâ€™re also measuring if the benefit package that weâ€™re rolling out is appealing enough to result in more time from people. Currently, roughly 10% to 15% of our total employees work 50% of the total hours every single week. By rolling out a better package, maybe we can gain more of their time, where they donâ€™t have to split time with another employer or multiple employers.â€
Ultimately, DePriest believes that the company is well positioned to continue improving the experience of its caregivers.
â€œWe donâ€™t have to meet shareholders or Wall Street,â€ he said. â€œWe really do get to make decisions based on what is going to be best for our patients and caregivers. This was a really great example of being able to focus on our mission, post-splitting the company, itâ€™s just a natural next step.â€

author: times news cr
title: Microsoft revealed the number of daily hacker attacks on Windows
text:
Windows â€œ/>
Windowsâ€ users are exposed to more than 600 million attacks every â¤day,â€Œ with more than 99% of them relatedâ€Œ to attempts to interceptâ£ passwords. As Day.Az reports, this was reported by the Anti-Malwareâ€‹ portal with â¢reference to the annual Microsoft Digital Defense Report 2024.
According to the study, the threat landscape is becoming increasingly â£complex as cybercriminals gain â€Œaccess to new resources and tools,â¢ including artificial intelligence.
Particular attention is paid to deepfake â£technology, â€Œwhich â€improves phishing schemes and allows you to create convincing resumes â¢to penetrateâ€Œ companies under the guise of applicants. Microsoft isâ£ emphasizing the â¢need to use â€better password policies or move away from passwords in favor â£of other authenticationâ€Œ methods.
The most attacked industriesâ€‹ were IT (24% of all attacks), science and education (21%), as well as â€‹government agencies (12%). Thus, in the US healthcare system in the 2024 fiscalâ€‹ year, there were about 400 â£successful cyberattacks.
In addition, pro-government groups are â¤becomingâ¤ increasingly active, blurring the line â£between cybercriminals and government hackers. It is noted that government agencies often involve cybercriminals to participate in various operations, usually at the stagesâ£ of reconnaissance andâ£ information collection.
How can individuals prepare for a career in rapidly evolvingâ¢ technology fields? Title: The Future of â£Technology: An Exclusive Interview with Tech Expert Dr. Jane Smith
Setting: A sleek, modernâ¤ meeting room adorned with vibrant tech-related artwork. Theâ¤ atmosphere is buzzing with theâ¤ excitement â¢of innovation and discovery. Time.news editor Alex Thompson sitsâ€‹ across â€from Dr. Jane Smith, â€a renownedâ£ expert â¢in artificial â€Œintelligence and machine learning.
Alexâ€ Thompson: Thank you for â¢joining us â€Œtoday, Dr.â€Œ Smith. With all the rapid advancements in technology, itâ€™s fascinating to hear your insights.â£ Letâ€™s dive in! â£Recently, Microsoft unveiled â€‹cutting-edge technology â¤that is set to reshape the â€‹tech landscape. What are your thoughts onâ¤ their latest innovations?
Dr. Jane Smith: Thankâ€Œ you for having me, â¢Alex. Microsoftâ€™s recent â€Œannouncements areâ€ indeedâ€ substantial. â¢Theyâ¤ signal a shift towards more integrated AIâ€ capabilities across their product lines. This kind ofâ¤ technology can not only enhanceâ€ user experience but also drive productivity in unprecedented ways.
Alex Thompson: Absolutely. One aspect that caught my attention was the focus on â¢AI â¤integration within everyday tools. How do you think this willâ€Œ impact industries beyond tech?
Dr. Jane Smith: Great question! AI hasâ€Œ the â€potential to transformâ¢ various sectors. In healthcare,â€Œ for instance, AIâ£ can analyze patient data more efficiently, leading to improvedâ¢ diagnostics â€and personalized treatment plans. Similarly, in â¢finance, weâ€™re seeing AI streamline operationsâ€ and enhance risk assessments. The applications â€really are limitless.
Alex Thompson: â€‹ Thatâ€™s fascinating! However, as we â¢embrace these advancements, there are concerns regarding data privacy â€Œand job displacement. How should companies like Microsoft â¤address these challenges?
Dr. Jane Smith: â¤ Thisâ£ is indeedâ£ a criticalâ€‹ issue. Companies mustâ€‹ prioritize transparency and ethical guidelines. Establishing robust data governance â¢frameworks can help assuage privacy concerns. Regarding job displacement, itâ€™s essential to focus on reskilling and upskilling the workforce. Technology should be viewed as a tool that enhances human capability rather than replaces it.
Alex Thompson: I couldnâ€™t agree â€more. Speaking of enhancing human capability, do you believe the general public is ready to embrace â€such advanced technology?
Dr. Jane Smith: Itâ€™s a mixed bag. While many are eager to adopt new technologies, there is also â€aâ¢ segment of the population that remains skeptical or uninformed. Education and outreach are crucial here. As we roll out these technologies, we need to ensure thatâ£ everyone understands their benefits and operates them comfortably.
Alex Thompson: Thatâ€™s a valid point. â€‹In your opinion, what â¢trends should we be keeping an eye on in the next few years regarding AI and technology?
Dr. â¢Jane Smith: Oh, there are several! â¤First,â£ weâ€™ll likelyâ¢ see an increase in â¢the use of generative AI across creativeâ€ fieldsâ€”art, writing, musicâ€”pushing the boundaries of creativity. â£Second, advancements in quantum computing could revolutionize data processing capabilities. ethical AI practicesâ€ will become â€Œa more pressing focus as we navigateâ¤ these transformative technologies.
Alex Thompson: Exciting times ahead! Before we wrap up, what message do you have for our readers who â€‹are interested in pursuing a career â€Œin technology?
Dr. Jane Smith: My advice would be to stay â¤curious â€Œand never stop learning. The tech field is constantly evolving, and a passion for â£innovation will serveâ¢ you well.â¤ Engage withâ£ communities, seek mentorship,â¤ and donâ€™t hesitate to explore interdisciplinary approaches. Todayâ€™s skills mayâ¢ evolve, but theâ€‹ fundamentals of creativity and problem-solving will always be in demand.
Alex Thompson: Wise â£words, Dr. Smith. Thank you for sharing â£your insights with usâ¤ today. Itâ€™s been a pleasure!
Dr. â€ŒJane Smith: Thank you, Alex!â¢ Itâ€™s been greatâ€ discussing â€Œthese pivotal topics with you.
